review_title: Great if you're in the right department
pros: Lots of opportunities on campus. Generally relaxed and you're given time to work on your studies.
cons: Some departments work you constantly during your clocked hours. Try to avoid the jobs where the boss doesn't seem to value your time as a student.

review_title: Failing to plan or planning to fail?
pros: Best school in the state for STEM degrees. Student to teacher ratio is fantastic. Lots of opportunities for students to be proactive and gain experience and gain knowledge by doing, not just reading. Socorro is what it is but if a small, focused, and highly dedicated education is what you are looking for then NMT is perfect.
cons: If you take a job with NMT you better like the salary you agree to because you will never see a raise or promotion. This is commonly known in higher education. A lot of recent turnover of VP's, Directors, and leaders which has brought a lot of challenges in terms of inexperience, nepotism, and cultural change. This once highly focused and thriving small school is starting starting to decline in terms of enrollment, experience, and fair pay. Leadership decided to hire two ultra-political VPs who came in and swiftly divided staff and faculty with their inclusivity jargon which has caused a lot of controversy and caused quite a few people to leave.

pros: This school does not have any pros.
cons: The school shows on paper the Salary as more than what the TA's take home. Recruiters lie to students, especially international students to get them here and then have them work at a much low consistent pay while the rest of the living costs and utilities go up. The increase that is given upon candidate status is worth nothing in this day and age and the school does not provide ways for students to make extra money while they pursue their education as they limit the number of credit hours everyone can work. It's a business model based on student exploitation. Also, almost all people are working more than one job title for the same or less pay. The money management is poor and job duties are given to people who are not at all qualified for them.

job_title: Office Manager in New York, NY
pros: Great working. Good managers etc.
cons: Salary could be better or more bonus

pros: Lots of great research opportunities
cons: Inconsistent work flow depending on where you are at in your research

job_title: Research Engineer II in Socorro, NM
pros: State pension verse 401k. Employer pay 60% medical premiums.
cons: Merit raises aren't regular, college normally rely on state cost of living raises only.

benefits

attitude towards humanities dept and instructors from admin, other depts and colleagues, even students

pros: Supportive staff, friendly community, and flexible hours.
cons: A small town with little to-do off campus

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Socorro, NM
pros: Everyone is very friendly and generous.
cons: The town itself is a little "dull", but I would consider it a calm and safe place.

pros: Nice and gentle colleagues in most departments.
cons: Very isolated location. 1 hr away from Albuequerque NM.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Socorro, NM
pros: Gain exposure and experience .
cons: Work was demanding as you combine academic and job

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Socorro, NM
pros: The Materials Engineering Department at NMT is absolutely fantastic. All of the faculty members are valuable and contribute in their own way. The research done by the department is absolutely fantastic and will afford students many opportunities going forward.
cons:
The school undervalues the department. 
Due to it being a smaller department (not many people know what materials engineering does) the school provides very limited support to the department.

review_title: Depends on the Professor but decent
pros: Good professors to work for
cons: Poor organization in the administration

pros:
The tips in the Summer are great
Some of the employees are nice
You'll never be bored between cooking, taking orders, cleaning, and prepping
cons:
One of the full-time employees makes life awful
You have to go in to see your schedule the Sunday before
They have employees cover register discrepancies out of their own pockets at the end of each shift
They often schedule just one person for a shift

pros: less stress and more enjoyable working environment. Leaves and benefits are above the average. No traffic, so can save a lot money on transportation.
cons: Raises are rare. So, negotiate for the best salary from the start. Hard to find new houses or comfortable apartments. If find any rent is not acceptable.

pros: Good experience, practical, analytical, problem solving
cons: Short, part time, summer, fall

pros: Flexibility of schedule while working on schooling
cons: Not a lot of supervisor while working

pros: Great place to launch a carrier
cons: Not challenging and need more hard problems

pros: The people here care about everyone
cons: I can't thin of anything

pros: Very good education system with lower tuition fee
cons: It's located in Socorro NM. Location is the only problem NMT

review_title: Its a good place to work as a student
pros: Easy and they aren't super strict on hours
cons: pay is not the best

pros: Great place to teach as university professor
cons: isolated city of Socorro and small community

pros: I do not have any project through out the year which is good thing for retired person
cons: really bad politics. I do not recommend to anyone especially software department at IRIS PASSCAL

pros:
Firstly, you actually get paid. That isn't a given for all student research positions, but at Tech you can actually earn money, while gaining work experience and working on classes.

Secondly, its a small campus and most professors are willing to put time into helping you out. If you need training on a new piece of equipment, access to their labs, for the most part they will make time for you and that is worth the world.
cons:
You still live in Socorro, which is awful in so many ways. 

You have to deal with the school's management, which is also awful.

review_title: Worst job I have ever had
pros: Hours were somewhat flexible.  Preferential treatment because I worked there.
cons: The common goal of my co-workers seemed to be to belittle each other.  Work was dominated by gossip and bad attitudes.  I have worked for fast food restaurants where I got more respect.  I had no idea it was acceptable to talk to other human beings the way I was talked to at this job.

pros:
Good place to start a career as an engineer.  Opportunity to work on systems-level engineering, project planning, logistics, testing, and fieldwork.  The largest draw would be the fieldwork and opportunity to travel globally.

Great opportunity to work with different industry/academic professionals and people/resource manage.

Location Pro:  PASSCAL is a building located in the northern reaches of the Chihuahuan desert.  The building is LEED certified, with plenty of space, natural lighting, and a very good chance you will have your own office with a window.  Beautiful surroundings.

Great work/life balance, great people to work with.

ProCon: Low cost of living.  Although you get what you way for.
cons:
Socorro.  Great place for rock climbing/bouldering.  That's about it.  I have learned very quickly that I will not thrive in such a small town, although the desert itself is beautiful.  A lot of people commute from Albuquerque/Los Lunas.  

The renumeration is abysmal.  Whatever your position might be, the pay in that field will be relatively sacrificial.  That might be a good way of looking at it; and it is up to you to decide if that fits within your 5 year goal.  See below.

The retirement fund needs serious looking into if you shall sign on.  When I was there, you were vested after 5 years, retroactive to the start of hire.  Meaning, you have to work at Tech for five years before you can keep your employer matching.  The retirement plan is strange, too; you should look into it (if it is transparent enough) and compare closely with other companies actually offering a matching 401k and a nationally known financial services company.

Explosions:  This has a cool factor, but being next to a mountain where Tech does explosive testing, windows will rattle.

review_title: Very friendly and laid back environment yet solve real-world difficult problems
pros: New Mexico Tech provides one of the best perks and benefits to employees. The people there are very friendly and I guess being a public institution your job is pretty secured!
cons: As in any government public institutions, you may encounter some politics every now and then but depending on who your supervisor is you can totally avoid it.

pros: Being a Residential Assistant taught me how to organize events, advertise, recruit, and mediate discussions. It was a useful position for a student working through college.
cons: New Mexico Tech has had many upsets to their senior management in recent years, mostly due to poor compensations for long periods on call, lack of forward movement, and personal disagreements.

pros: Education is good and so are most professors. Class sizes are very small and work load is manageable. for the price this is a great university and future job prospects look promising.
cons: Student wages are low but that is to be expected. the community is very small and has an odd dynamic between the locals and the university employees.

review_title: Flexible research work for undergraduate students
job_title: Student Lab Assistant in Socorro, NM
pros: Small town environment, everyone knows everyone. Very flexible work schedule and easy to get a job. A wonderful opportunity for undergraduate students looking to add something to their resume and earn a big of pocket money.
cons: Sometimes the small town feeling is too much! Pay is not stellar, but the flexibility and experience gained more than compensates.

review_title: They have treated me well over the last 4 years.
pros: I get to work with research and academia. It can be very rewarding and the hours are quite flexible. I can come and go as I please.
cons: As with the pros, the con is that I get to work with research and academia.  It can at times be quite a hassle to get things done and there is a significant bureaucracy.

pros:
Great people to work with
Pay is decent
Excellent experience
Very open and willing to teach you and develop you
Friendly people
Experts in the field
cons:
Some politics but nothing excessive or more than other companies
A lot of competition for engineering positions makes it difficult to obtain one

job_title: Associate Grant Director in Socorro, NM
pros: Highly respected STEM research institute; small school with excellent faculty, staff, and administration. Wide variety of cultural and ethnic population. Affordable housing market and low cost-of-living.
cons: Small town, limited amenities, high desert geography. Funding always challenging for advancing research and increasing pay. Recent increases in student population have raised student-to-teacher ratios.

pros: I loved the people I worked with in the Post office, ASAP program, and even the IT department.
cons: The pay was not the best, as a student who depends on the money to eat it can be difficult if there is not enough hours at work or something comes up.

pros: Very encouraging, they make you think a lot too very intuitive work so i guess it was challenging too. A very friendly environment
cons: Few seniors constantly give misleading guidance. Internal politics like any other organization and It is very important to find the right person to work under

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Socorro, NM
pros: The course I teach is for a lab undergraduates take. It doesn't take too much time out of the week. Good student to teacher ratio.
cons: No health insurance through job for graduate students.

pros: Good first job in corporate-like setting. Provides opportunity to grow. Nurtures familiarity with campus and town.
cons: Lack of regular feedback and employee performance/pay reviews.

pros: My supervisers understood that school comes first. They were always understanding.
cons: It'd be nice to be paid more, even if I was already above minimum wage
